seg.seg: ... brings (?) ... Having fixed his blue gaze upon the sick, he is sad with all his heart ... (and says: "...)
... this world is led! || in gautamakapil || Some look lethargic, the eyes cast down ... [1a]
... their heads [are] battered. [1b] Some are half covered with wounds, of some the bellies ...
... their skin ... [1d] The hearts of some are bounding and they are very harshly tormented. [2a] Others ...
Of some the exhalation is feeble, and they just shrug their shoulders. [2c] Others (have) a disease of the mouth and jaundice ...
miserable [with] tuberculosis, or with tumors. [3a] [Their] lips [are] parched with thirst, and they are bound only to their bed[s] because of sorrow ...
... some have become ... and reflect only anxiety. 3[d]" || Thereupon king Mahendrasena ...
... with his blue gaze drinking as it were out of pity ...
... he says to the ministers || in strivighāt ||: "See this low saṃsāra, [which is] very horrible! [1a] ...
... [1b] ... He exchanged their sorrowful appearances. [1c] Through the caläm of everyone's own deed ...

a2 ... is this world. || In Gautamakapi metre || Some of these looked distressed [their] eyes hollow [with suffering]

a3 their heads battered [and] yet others again among them [were] covered in wounds [and] some with their stomachs' ...

a4 [and] their skin [lifeless]. The käryāñ of some of them are protruding [and they are] very grievously tormented, [and yet] others [again] [are]

a5 Some have feeble (dejected) respiration and [their] shoulders move only upwards. The others [have] a disease of the mouth [and] jaundice.

b1 With consumption [and] swellings/tumors ... the wretched creatures, [have] [their] lips parched with thirst, and [are] completely bound to their beds with [their] afflictions.

b2 Some [have] become ...: [And] they reflect only anxiety. 3. Thereupon king Mahendrasena ...

b3 With the ... gaze, as if drinking [them in] out of [his] great pity [for them]

b4 says to his ministers. || In Strivighāt metre || Behold ye this common saṃsāra together with [so] many!

b5 [He] exchanged the sorrowful appearance of the humans. With the of each deed [sic - TI].
